column2: PART ONE

column2: Chapter 1
column3: Chapter one

column2: Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.
column3: Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.

column2: Everything was in confusion in the Oblonskys' house.
column3: Everything was in confusion in the Oblonskys' house.

column2: The wife had discovered that the husband was carrying on an intrigue with a French girl, who had been a governess in their family, and she had announced to her husband that she could not go on living in the same house with him. This position of affairs had now lasted three days, and not only the husband and wife themselves, but all the members of their family and household, were painfully conscious of it.
column3: The wife had discovered that the husband was carrying on an intrigue with a French girl, who had been a governess in their family, and she had announced to her husband that she could not go on living in the same house with him. This position of affairs had now lasted three days, and not only the husband and wife themselves, but all the members of their family and household, were painfully conscious of it.

column2: Every person in the house felt that there was no sense in their living together, and that the stray people brought together by chance in any inn had more in common with one another than they, the members of the family and household of the Oblonskys.
column3: Every person in the house felt that there was no sense in their living together, and that the stray people brought together by chance in any inn had more in common with one another than they, the members of the family and household of the Oblonskys.

column2: The wife did not leave her own room, the husband had not been at home for three days.
column3: The wife did not leave her own room, the husband had not been at home for three days.

column2: The children ran wild all over the house; the English governess quarreled with the housekeeper, and wrote to a friend asking her to look out for a new situation for her; the man-cook had walked off the day before just at dinner time; the kitchen-maid, and the coachman had given warning.
column3: The children ran wild all over the house; the English governess quarreled with the housekeeper, and wrote to a friend asking her to look out for a new situation for her; the man cook had walked off the day before just at dinner time; the kitchen maid, and the coachman had given warning.

column2: Three days after the quarrel, Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky--Stiva, as he was called in the fashionable world--woke up at his usual hour, that is, at eight o'clock in the morning, not in his wife's bedroom, but on the leather-covered sofa in his study.
column3: Three days after the quarrel, Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky-Stiva, as he was called in the fashionable world-woke up at his usual hour, that is, at eight o'clock in the morning, not in his wife's bedroom, but on the leather covered sofa in his study.

column2: He turned over his stout, well-cared-for person on the springy sofa, as though he would sink into a long sleep again; he vigorously embraced the pillow on the other side and buried his face in it; but all at once he jumped up, sat up on the sofa, and opened his eyes.
column3: He turned over his stout, well cared for person on the springy sofa, as though he would sink into a long sleep again; he vigorously embraced the pillow on the other side and buried his face in it; but all at once he jumped up, sat up on the sofa, and opened his eyes.

column2: Yes, yes, how was it now? he thought, going over his dream.
column3: Yes, yes, how was it now? he thought, going over his dream.

column2: Now, how was it?	Now, how was it?
column3: true

column2: To be sure!
column3: To be sure!

column2: Alabin was giving a dinner at Darmstadt; no, not Darmstadt, but something American.
column3: Alabin was giving a dinner at Darmstadt; no, not Darmstadt, but something American.

column2: Yes, but then, Darmstadt was in America.
column3: Yes, but then, Darmstadt was in America.

column2: Yes, Alabin was giving a dinner on glass tables, and the tables sang, _Il mio tesoro_--not _Il mio tesoro_ though, but something better, and there were some sort of little decanters on the table, and they were women, too," he remembered.
column3: Yes, Alabin was giving a dinner on glass tables, and the tables sang, underscore Il mio tesoro underscore--not underscore Il mio tesoro underscore though, but something better, and there were some sort of little decanters on the table, and they were women, too," he remembered.

column2: Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes twinkled gaily, and he pondered with a smile. "Yes, it was nice, very nice.
column3: Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes twinkled gaily, and he pondered with a smile. "Yes, it was nice, very nice.

column2: There was a great deal more that was delightful, only there's no putting it into words, or even expressing it in one's thoughts awake." And noticing a gleam of light peeping in beside one of the serge curtains, he cheerfully dropped his feet over the edge of the sofa, and felt about with them for his slippers, a present on his last birthday, worked for him by his wife on gold-colored morocco.
column3: There was a great deal more that was delightful, only there's no putting it into words, or even expressing it in one's thoughts awake." And noticing a gleam of light peeping in beside one of the serge curtains, he cheerfully dropped his feet over the edge of the sofa, and felt about with them for his slippers, a present on his last birthday, worked for him by his wife on gold colored morocco.

column2: And, as he had done every day for the last nine years, he stretched out his hand, without getting up, towards the place where his dressing-gown always hung in his bedroom.
column3: And, as he had done every day for the last nine years, he stretched out his hand, without getting up, towards the place where his dressing gown always hung in his bedroom.

column2: And thereupon he suddenly remembered that he was not sleeping in his wife's room, but in his study, and why: the smile vanished from his face, he knitted his brows.
column3: And thereupon he suddenly remembered that he was not sleeping in his wife's room, but in his study, and why: the smile vanished from his face, he knitted his brows.

column2: Ah, ah, ah!	Ah, ah, ah!
column3: false

column2: Oo!..." he muttered, recalling everything that had happened.
column3: Oo!..." he muttered, recalling everything that had happened.

column2: And again every detail of his quarrel with his wife was present to his imagination, all the hopelessness of his position, and worst of all, his own fault.
column3: And again every detail of his quarrel with his wife was present to his imagination, all the hopelessness of his position, and worst of all, his own fault.

column2: Yes, she won't forgive me, and she can't forgive me.	Yes, she won't forgive me, and she can't forgive me.
column3: true

column2: And the most awful thing about it is that it's all my fault--all my fault, though I'm not to blame.
column3: And the most awful thing about it is that it's all my fault-all my fault, though I'm not to blame.

column2: That's the point of the whole situation," he reflected.
column3: That's the point of the whole situation," he reflected.

column2: Oh, oh, oh! he kept repeating in despair, as he remembered the acutely painful sensations caused him by this quarrel.
column3: Oh, oh, oh! he kept repeating in despair, as he remembered the acutely painful sensations caused him by this quarrel.

column2: Most unpleasant of all was the first minute when, on coming, happy and good-humored, from the theater, with a huge pear in his hand for his wife, he had not found his wife in the drawing-room, to his surprise had not found her in the study either, and saw her at last in her bedroom with the unlucky letter that revealed everything in her hand.
column3: Most unpleasant of all was the first minute when, on coming, happy and good humored, from the theater, with a huge pear in his hand for his wife, he had not found his wife in the drawing room, to his surprise had not found her in the study either, and saw her at last in her bedroom with the unlucky letter that revealed everything in her hand.

column2: She, his Dolly, forever fussing and worrying over household details, and limited in her ideas, as he considered, was sitting perfectly still with the letter in her hand, looking at him with an expression of horror, despair, and indignation.
column3: She, his Dolly, forever fussing and worrying over household details, and limited in her ideas, as he considered, was sitting perfectly still with the letter in her hand, looking at him with an expression of horror, despair, and indignation.

column2: What's this?	What's this?
column3: true

column2: this?" she asked, pointing to the letter.
column3: this?" she asked, pointing to the letter.

column2: And at this recollection, Stepan Arkadyevitch, as is so often the case, was not so much annoyed at the fact itself as at the way in which he had met his wife's words.
column3: And at this recollection, Stepan Arkadyevitch, as is so often the case, was not so much annoyed at the fact itself as at the way in which he had met his wife's words.

column2: There happened to him at that instant what does happen to people when they are unexpectedly caught in something very disgraceful.
column3: There happened to him at that instant what does happen to people when they are unexpectedly caught in something very disgraceful.

column2: He did not succeed in adapting his face to the position in which he was placed towards his wife by the discovery of his fault.
column3: He did not succeed in adapting his face to the position in which he was placed towards his wife by the discovery of his fault.

column2: Instead of being hurt, denying, defending himself, begging forgiveness, instead of remaining indifferent even--anything would have been better than what he did do--his face utterly involuntarily (reflex spinal action, reflected Stepan Arkadyevitch, who was fond of physiology)--utterly involuntarily assumed its habitual, good-humored, and therefore idiotic smile.
column3: Instead of being hurt, denying, defending himself, begging forgiveness, instead of remaining indifferent even-anything would have been better than what he did do-his face utterly involuntarily (reflex spinal action, reflected Stepan Arkadyevitch, who was fond of physiology)--utterly involuntarily assumed its habitual, good humored, and therefore idiotic smile.

column2: This idiotic smile he could not forgive himself.
column3: This idiotic smile he could not forgive himself.

column2: Catching sight of that smile, Dolly shuddered as though at physical pain, broke out with her characteristic heat into a flood of cruel words, and rushed out of the room.
column3: Catching sight of that smile, Dolly shuddered as though at physical pain, broke out with her characteristic heat into a flood of cruel words, and rushed out of the room.

column2: Since then she had refused to see her husband.
column3: Since then she had refused to see her husband.

column2: It's that idiotic smile that's to blame for it all, thought Stepan Arkadyevitch.
column3: It's that idiotic smile that's to blame for it all, thought Stepan Arkadyevitch.

column2: But what's to be done?	But what's to be done?
column3: true

column2: What's to be done?" he said to himself in despair, and found no answer.
column3: What's to be done?" he said to himself in despair, and found no answer.

column2: Chapter 2
column3: Chapter two

column2: Stepan Arkadyevitch was a truthful man in his relations with himself.
column3: Stepan Arkadyevitch was a truthful man in his relations with himself.

column2: He was incapable of deceiving himself and persuading himself that he repented of his conduct.
column3: He was incapable of deceiving himself and persuading himself that he repented of his conduct.

column2: He could not at this date repent of the fact that he, a handsome, susceptible man of thirty-four, was not in love with his wife, the mother of five living and two dead children, and only a year younger than himself.
column3: He could not at this date repent of the fact that he, a handsome, susceptible man of thirty four, was not in love with his wife, the mother of five living and two dead children, and only a year younger than himself.

column2: All he repented of was that he had not succeeded better in hiding it from his wife.
column3: All he repented of was that he had not succeeded better in hiding it from his wife.

column2: But he felt all the difficulty of his position and was sorry for his wife, his children, and himself.
column3: But he felt all the difficulty of his position and was sorry for his wife, his children, and himself.

column2: Possibly he might have managed to conceal his sins better from his wife if he had anticipated that the knowledge of them would have had such an effect on her.
column3: Possibly he might have managed to conceal his sins better from his wife if he had anticipated that the knowledge of them would have had such an effect on her.

column2: He had never clearly thought out the subject, but he had vaguely conceived that his wife must long ago have suspected him of being unfaithful to her, and shut her eyes to the fact.
column3: He had never clearly thought out the subject, but he had vaguely conceived that his wife must long ago have suspected him of being unfaithful to her, and shut her eyes to the fact.

column2: He had even supposed that she, a worn-out woman no longer young or good-looking, and in no way remarkable or interesting, merely a good mother, ought from a sense of fairness to take an indulgent view.
column3: He had even supposed that she, a worn out woman no longer young or good looking, and in no way remarkable or interesting, merely a good mother, ought from a sense of fairness to take an indulgent view.

column2: It had turned out quite the other way.
column3: It had turned out quite the other way.
